title: What is FEMA?
desc: FEMA regulates foreign exchange transactions to promote orderly development of the foreign exchange market in India.

title: Who needs FEMA compliance?
desc: Individuals and businesses involved in foreign exchange, foreign investment, or cross-border transactions.

title: What are FEMA penalties for non-compliance?
desc: Penalties include fines and, in severe cases, prosecution under the act.

title: How do I repatriate funds under FEMA?
desc: Funds can be repatriated through authorized dealers with proper documentation.

title: What is the role of RBI in FEMA?
desc: RBI acts as the primary regulator issuing guidelines and approvals under FEMA.

title: Is FEMA applicable to NRIs?
desc: Yes, FEMA governs NRIs' investments, property transactions, and remittances in India.

title: What is an LRS under FEMA?
desc: Liberalized Remittance Scheme (LRS) allows residents to remit up to $250,000 per financial year for specified purposes.

title: Can foreign companies invest in Indian startups under FEMA?
desc: Yes, subject to compliance with FEMA and FDI regulations.

title: What are the FEMA guidelines for acquiring property abroad?
desc: Indian residents can acquire property abroad under LRS or through inherited means.

title: What is an ECB under FEMA?
desc: External Commercial Borrowings (ECBs) are loans availed by Indian entities from foreign lenders.

title: Are cryptocurrencies covered under FEMA?
desc: Currently, there is no explicit regulation under FEMA for cryptocurrencies.

title: How do I report foreign investments in India?
desc: Investments must be reported to RBI through forms like FCGPR or FCTRS.

title: What is FEMA's role in foreign trade?
desc: FEMA ensures that all foreign trade transactions comply with prescribed guidelines.

title: What are FEMA regulations for outbound investments?
desc: Outbound investments require prior approval from RBI under FEMA guidelines.

title: How do I regularize FEMA non-compliance?
desc: Non-compliance can be rectified through compounding applications to the RBI.
